The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and traid de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £19.4.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate Steamers do not proceed at Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday attached to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The wearther now is much the same daily, sultry and trying. Today a light N.W. breeze is blowing and the barometer falling. Some wind may be expected towards the close of the day.

SATURDAY, JUNE 30, 1906.

div.head: TALODI.
div.p: Now that the close of the Denishwai tragedy enables the public to turn with relief to other topics of interest, we hope that the prasie due to the Moudir of Kordofan will be gernerously granted by those who have not already forgotten the Talodi incident, and are still aware that in relieving the garrison and defeating the insurgents, O'Connell Bey performed a very fine feat of arms. The natural difficulties which impeded his march from El Obeid were terrific: the men and transport animals waded through water and mud for days, and the Sudan, in popular imagination, a region of mirages, heat, and sandstorms rivalled for the time this Polish marshes and the Manchurian plain in autumn. The expedition fought its way through miles of quagmire, and after a march of over 250 miles relieved Talodi and on the 14th inst. overthrew the rebels and their allies of the Jebel El Liri, inflicting on them a decisive and crushing reverse.

In campaigns against savage or semi barbarous peoples, a victory which is unaccompanies by tangible results and does not bring with it the rout and dispersal of the hostile forces, is often only less fatal in its consequences than a disaster. The history of the earlier Sudanese campaigns teems with examples of this sort. General Graham's forces in 1884 and 1885 defeated the armies of Osman Digna at El Tel and Tamai, at Hasheen and at Tofrek, but in none of these actions did our troops succeed in crushing the rebels. The Hadendowa dervishes lost heavily, and their attacks were uniformly repulsed, but they never suffered an exterminating defeast such as overtook Wad el Nejumi at Toski, and the main forces of the Dervish Empire at Atbara and Omdurman. The rebellion lasted for years after Tofrek in the Eastern Sudan, and in the Boer war the number of indecisive victories in which our brave troops, after driving the enemy from a position, found themselves no better off than before, was one of the causes of the prolongation of the struggle.

Another very satisfactory feature of the campaign was the support given to the column by the neighbouring tribes. The Nubas, who have long suffered from Arab raids and who yet, in Major O'Connell's own words quoted by Lord Cromer, "rather enjoy a fight," assisted the Talodi garrison, and Mek Abou Sikina, with 500 warriors armed with spears and guns of various patterns, took part in the storming of the rebel stronghold. Nor were the Baggara behindhand. Several clans of this fierce tribe aided the attack, and the fact that the people of Jebel Gadir, the first centre of Mahdism in Kordofan, were as loyal as the pagan Nubas, shows that the populance, as a whole, respects the strength and is content with the administration of the Government. The political conditions of Southern Kordofan are still disturbed. An article which we publish today shows that outbreaks are almost bound to trouble the Government from time to time in the Nuba country, but as the wealth of the Sudan increases, the maintenance of garrisons at the more important points in the huge province - which is as large as France - will become less and less costly. Nothing is to be gained by spreading a few companies over a few thousand square miles.

div.head: SAMOS.
div.p: We recently described as of "speculative doubt" the position of the Bey of Samos. Our words might be said to hvae been tinged, unwittingly, with a certain sense of the prophetical, for a Havas telegram today from Vathy reports that the Constituent Assembly has decided to depose Janko Effendi Bithynos. "The more the changes, the less changes." Such are the political conditions of the beautiful Aegean Isle that it is seldom that the Bey manages to keep office for any length of time. As long as he has the wherewithal to buy the necessary number of vots, all is well, but once the bakshish begins to run short, and agitation, like the present, which is led by the unpaid opposition, is set in motion to replace him by another plutocrat. In material prosperity the Isle has made considerable progress, the port of Vathy, which is also the capital, affording ample harbourage; but in the arena of politics the true instincts of the Hellenic genius come into play, and in the case of Samos it may verily be said that it is the cue constitutional body politic which has proved, after more than half a century of life, a permanent failure and warning to al other Greek communities under the aegis of the Sultan. The question of a candidate to fill the coming vacancy is sure to crop up and it is not unlikely that the list submitted to M. Gangos, the Agent of Samos at Constatinople, will include such a well-knwon name as Karatheodory; that Phanariote family which enjoys such high esteem at the Palace and Phanar.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
THE BRINDISI MAIL.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday.

div.head: Hackmeyer Orchestra.
div.p: The Hackmeyer Orchestra will play in the inner room of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's bar every Sunday from 10.30 a.m. to 1.30 p.m.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: The imports of coal form January 1 to June 28 amounted to 600,907 tons, as compared with 458,233 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: A.S.C.
div.p: The polo ground will not be available for polo or golf on Monday the 2nd July, as arrangements have been made to water it on that day.

div.head: Stabbing Affray.
div.p: A quarrel took place yesterday between two butches of Souk el Gouma, one of whom stabbed the other in the left side with a knife, causing serious injuries.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: A fresh case of plague is reported at Alexandria today, and in consequence the quarantine measures on the departure of vessels have been reimposed.

div.head: Tramway Accident.
div.p: An Armenian was knocked down yesterday by a tramcar in Sisters street and sustained serious injuries in the head. He was taken to hospital and the wattman arrested.

div.head: Cairo Law School.
div.p: The authorities of the Cairo Law School have dismissed nine pupils, according to the new regulations of that school, for having failed to pass into a higher class at the last examination.

div.head: Turkish Telegraphs.
div.p: The installation of a telegraphic line between Yambo and Medina, by the Turkish Government, was inaugurated on the 21st ult., when the first telegraphic pole was erected at Yambo.

div.head: Cobra Bite.
div.p: At Kafr Ammar, recently, a native was bitten by a large cobra. He ran home as fast as possible and binding his foot, rode to the house of Mr. C.W. Wilkinson, who made two incisions upwards and across the fang marks, 1 1/2 inches apart, and then rubed in the permanganate of potash, powdering it between finger and thumb. The man was cured. It is just a year since the above treatment was advocated in the "Times," and it deserves to widely known.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The Geisha was again given at the Alhambra last night with the usual success, after so many performances this season. It is perhaps the only English musical play which could stand repetition so often in this country. A proof of its popularity is the fact that it has recently been "revived" at Daly's Theatre, London. Last night, Mr. Sidney Jones's pretty, delicate, lilting music came back as fresh as ever. No mere commonplace "tunefulness" could ever do that. When a "Bill Bailey" dies he is buried fathoms deep, never to rise again. "One cannot imagine a revival of, say, The Orchid - to choose as example one of the most popular of the ordinary musical comedies. The fact is, of course, that Mr. Jones has given us a score of charming opera bouffe, in which tune is allied to grace, and melody to musicianly treatment. The Geisha is not mere jingly. As already announced, it will be given on Wednesday next in aid of the Maltese Benevolent Society of Alexandria.
H.E. Ibrahim Facha Naghib, Second Secretary to the Ministry of the Interior, left yesterday for Cairo.
Blattner Bey, chief interpreter to the British Headquarters at Alexandria, has been granted three months leave of absence.

Among the many visitors staying at the Beau-Rivage we notice. Capt. and Mrs. S.S. Flowers and family Mr. R. Rolo, Mr. and Mrs. Zeberi, Miss Nassif, Mr. Ph. div.head: LONDON RAILWAYS FLOODED.
PHENOMENAL RAINFALL.
MORE EARTHQUAKE SHOCKS
div.p: A phenomenal rainfall took place in the South East of England, this morning, of over two inches. The London railways are flooded and traffic blocked. The basements of theatres and shops are inundated and fire brigades are busy pumping them out.
Slight earthquake shocks have been felt in Wales and at Croydon. (Reuter)

div.head: FREQUENT FIGHTING IN SOUTHERN NIGERIA.
div.p: Frequent fighting is taking place in Southern Nigeria. Captain Wayling's force lost 34 killed or wounded, he himself being slightly wounded; his force halted at Utah. Captain Rudkin, while moving to Captain Wayling's assistance, lost 13 killed or wounded and was compelled to return to Agbor. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BIELOSTOK MASSACRES.
div.p: Military outbreaks are reported at Vladikavkaz and Samara, where the regiments have drafted demands for a better position similar to the Preobrajensky Regiment. All the officers of the latter regiment will be court martialled. (Reuter)
The 1st Battalion of the Preobrajensky Regiment has been transferred to the Line and deprived of the priviliges of the Guards.
The Guard at Peterhof has been augmented. Four sotnias of Cossacks have arrived here in order to guard the military and naval work shops. (Reuter)
All the officers of Preobrahjensky's regiment will be court martialled. (Havas)

div.head: REPATRIATION OF RUSSIAN TROOPS.
div.p: The last detachment of the Russian troops in Manchuria have left and are on their way to Russia, with the exception of a small number who are returning in 1907. (Reuter)

div.head: EXPLOSION ON H.M.S. ESSEX.
One Killed, Four Injured.
div.p: One seaman has been killed and lieutenant and three seaman injured, by a gun explosion on the cruiser Essex during the maneuvers, whilst firing a six inch blank charge.

div.head: KAISER INTERESTED IN COTTON CULTIVATION.
div.p: The Emperor William has received the Cotton Congress Committee at Kiel, and stated that he is deeply interested in the extension of cotton cultivation.

div.head: MILLIONAIRE CHARGED WITH WILFUL MURDER.
div.p: Mr. Thaw has been indicted with wilful murder. Public opinion sides with Mr. Thaw owing to the questionable character of Mr. White. (Reuter)

div.head: SAMOS PRINCIPALITY.
div.p: The Chamber has decided to depose Bithynos. (Havas)

div.head: CONVERSION OF ITALIAN RENTE.
div.p: Parliament has voted the conversion of the Rente at 3.75%. (Havas)

div.head: DEATH OF FRENCH ACADEMICIAN.
div.p: The Academician Sorel is dead. (Havas)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Cricket. Somerset beat Hampshire by an innings and 151 runs. Sussex beat Middlesex by an innings and 101 runs. (Reuter)

div.head: DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
WORLD'S PRESS & VERDICT.
BRITISH GOVERNMENT'S ATTITUDE.
div.p: The world's press is almost unanimous in approving the sentences on and the executions of the murderers of Lieutenant Bull.
The Little Englandism of Byles and Co. in the House of Commons met with the decision which it deserves.

There is a general feeling of satisfaction that the Egyptian Government have shown their intention to strongly suppress all attempts at lawlessness on the part of natives against Europeans. It is hoped that the Denishwai affair will prove a wholesome lesson.
Sir Edward Grey's firm answers in the House of Commons are a satisfactory proof of the Government's intention to uphold the actions of the Egyptian and British authorities in Egypt.

Our French and native contemporaries continue to discuss the execution of the Denishwai criminals and the verdict of the court. "Le Progiès" remarks, that the Denishwai outrage shows an atavistic tendency towards a return to sem0barbarism in spite of the gradual infiltration of civilised ideas among the masses. "The embryonic state which will one day make a nation which has received from Europe a mandate to watch over the pacific and progressive evolution of Egypt has the right to protect the country against herself."

"Such being Great Britain's mission in Egypt we feel that one of our contemporaries was unhappily inspired in comparing the Egypt of Mohamed Aly with the Egypt of today, and arriving at the conclusion that the British uniform has no right to more respect than the garments of the European civilian. But the British uniform represents in Egypt that element of intelligent force without which all attempts at social organisation would be vain. It therefore deserves to be defended in a manner proportionate to the ill-feeling that may be aroused by the accomplishment of its duties. One of our contemporaries has already hinted that the tribunal was swayed by religious prejudice, a hint that can only discredit it among the Moslem public of the country."

"Al Moayad," on the other hand, complains that premeditation was not proven, despite the finding of the Court. It asserts that the verdict was a British demonstration, and that hundreds of letters have reached it complaining of the severity of the verdict and the weakness of counsel for the defence.
"Al Zaher," in a violent article, declares that the country is becoming more and more rapidly enslaved, etc., etc.

div.head: MAJOR PINE COFFIN'S CONDITION
div.p: A rumour is current in Cairo that Major Pine-Coffin was taken out of the train at Tantah on his way to Alexandria from Chibin-el-Kom on Thursday suffering from a paralytic stroke, but we understand to be untrue.

A report has been received at Cairo Headquarters that on arrival at Alexandria Major Pine-Coffin was readmitted into hospital for the treatment of his broken arm, but no other illness has been noticed in the report.

The probable truth of the case is that Major Pine Coffin fainted. Our special correspondent at the trial remarked that he appeared to be suffering considerably from the serious injuries from whihc he had received, and that on leaving Chibin el Kom he seemed far from well, the strain of the trial probably having weakened him.

div.head: QUESTIONS OF EMPIRE.
"CHEAP MISSIONARIES" v. CHEAP POSTAGE.
div.p: The annual meeting of the Victoria League, the object of which is to promote more intimate understanding between the Mother Country and the Colonies, was held last week at the Imperial Institute. The Countess of Jersey presided.

Mr. Sydney Buxton, M.P., moved a resolution commending the objects of the League. He said they desired to eliminate party questions from all Colonial policy and from all questions of Empire. (Hear, hear.) Although he had only been Postmaster General for six months, he was already convinced that postal facilities and postal matters were much more important than anything else throughout the Empire. The Imperial Penny Post was a great step in the right direction. The only colonies now left out were a few islands in the Pacific, inhabited chiefly by cannibals, who cared more for cheap missionaries than cheap postage. (Laughter.)
Sir Lewis Michell seconded, and Sir John Cockburn supported, the resolution, which was unanimoulsy adopted.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE.
div.p: Penny postage between Egypt and the British Central Africa Protectorate comes into force tomorrow, on which date to reduction of postage between Egypt and Italy, Erythrea, and Benadix will also come into force, letters for these countries being taxed five millièmes for every 15 grammes.
On the 1st August next penny postage will be established between Egypt and Zanzibar.

div.head: MR. SCHILIZZI'S DEATH.
TRAGEDY OF BLINDNESS.
div.p: Some tragic facts were recalled at the inquest yesterady week on Mr. Demetrius George Schilizzi, 59, a partner in the firm of Messrs. Mayhew and Schilizzi, stock brokers, who shot himself at the London Stock Exchange on Thursday.
The Coroner remarked that it had been his painful duty to hold an inquest on a son of the deceased two years ago-a son who committed suicide through failing sight.

Mr. Scharmango, an East India merchant, and brother-in-law of the deceased, told the jury that recently Mr. Shilizzi had been troubled on account of his second son, who was deaf and dumb. Decreased had every reason to suppose that he also would go blind. This was the last straw.

Mr. Schilizzi had been depressed and morbid for some time, and was afflicted in his eyes. He suffered from catarrh, and seemed to fear that he would lose his sight, like his suicide son. HE had actually gone blind for two days, but recovered, and a doctor had treated him for hysteria and nervousness.

On a paper found on Mr. Schilizzi after his death was written the following note:- "I wish my body to be taken home after the inquest, and hope this, my last request, will be carried out. I have no book on the Stock Exchange. - D.G. Schilizzi." With reference to the book, it was mentioned that there were no outstanding debts.
Another letter, which the Coroner thought should be read, was addressed to the dead man's personal friend. It commenced. "No domestic trouble has anything to do with my action today."
The jury returned a verdict of "Suicide while of unsound mind."

div.head: ISLAM AND JAPAN.
MISSIONARY DEPARTS.
div.p: Sheikh Ali Ahmed El-girgawi, propietor of the native weekly "Al Irshad," left yesterday for Japan. The sheikh, who intends to preach Islam to the Japanese, will first visit Tunis, where he will meet a sheikh who is prepared to accompany him on his voyage, and both preachers will then proceed to Calcutta, where another sheikh of Egyptian origin will join them and the mission will then continue its journey to Japan.

"Al-Irshad" will not appear for three months during the absence of its editor, Sheikh Ali Ahmed, who declares that he has received no financial aid from Egypt and would refuse to accept any were it offered him.

div.head: KHEDIVE IN PARIS.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has left for Paris. (H.)

div.head: THE MENSHAWI WAKES.
div.p: The revenue of the wakis of the late Menshawi Pacha for 1905 amounted to P.T. 4,834,001. After deducting expenses and debts, the balance, amounting to P.T. 268,100, is to be distributed as follows: P.T. 200,000 to the Hedjaz Railway and to the widows and orphans of Turkish troops; P.T. 40m000 for the benefit of the girls' school of Tantah, under the administration of the El-Orwa El-Woska Society; and P.T. 22,100 to the Moslem Benevolent Society's schools.

div.head: SOUTHERN KORDOFAN.
THE COUNTRY AND ITS PEOPLE.
div.p: Southern Kordofan, the scene of the recent expedition against the rebels of Talodi, is in its natural configuration one of the strangest countries in the world. An immense plain, burnt to a desert in the dry season, except where forests of gum-bearing acacias shelter the soil, a marsh during the rains, and a meadow for a weeks after them, covers an area half as large as France. All over it are scattered rocky kopjes, the mountains of the Nuba tribes, precipitous and barren. There are scarecely any ranges or groups of heights. The mountains rise isolated masses, from the open plain, and in their rocky recesses the aborignies of the country have built their strongholds. The mountains are for the Nuba, the plains for the Baggara clans of pastoral Arabs, who, whether they came from the Nile or, like the Tungurs of Darfour, crossed the Sahara from Barbary and entered the Eastern Sudan from Wadai and Bornu, soon made themselves masters of the entire plain region. The Nubas, whom they displaced, were compelled to betake themselves for safety the mountains.

A pastoral warrior race is usually inclined to supplement its wives by female slaves, and itself disdaining manual labour, to give employment to such of its neighbours as it can catch. The early Turks, the Mongols, and the Arab conquerors of North Africa acquired male and female slaves. The Boer Vortrekkers, if they most disdained to mix their blood with that of the Kaffirs, found them useful cowherds, watchmen, and domestic servants. Certain races of ants who employ themselves in fighting and carrying away slaves and the aphides or honeydew insects which are their cattle, employ their slaves as milkers and cattle tenders, workmen and personal servants. Entomologists assert that these warrior ants, however redoubtable in war, are the most helpless creatures in private life and require even to be fed and cleaned by their slaves.

The nomad Arabs of Kordofan, though they never reached such a depth of dependence, soon found their Nuba slaves indispensable. A desert Azah would not dream of employing his sons in any manual labour a Nuba would do the work. If a spring or well enabled him to raise a crop of dhurra, was he, a free born Hadouin, to dig and delve. Not he, when Nuba heathens could be caught with little risk and trouble and persuaded by the ggentle argument of the kourbash that they should be proud to work balash for good, Moslems of Arab blood.

Driven from the plains, the Nubas sought refuge in the hills taht are scattered over every district of the country. Here they were safe from destruction, for the nolay and picturesque riders with their long guns and longer lances could not attack the fortified mountain village, where the blacks with the advantages of ground and cover were as good men as they. Unable to storm the hills they roamed over the plains watching their chanors, which came when the blacks, weary of a short commons among the rocks, began to plant dhurra on the plain at their foot. The Beggara watched them like cats and now and again the raiders saw their chance and rode in, slaying and taking captive. Their horses and camels took them rapidly out of danger if repulsed by the blacks, who dared not follow the aggressors far from the heights.

It was not surprising that the blacks soon lost wahtever civilisation they had once possessed. The ancestors- according to some authors - of the Berberin, who declare that they originally came from Kordofan, they were partly Christianised by refugees from the Christian kingdom of Dongls, and traces of Christian influence survive among these pagans. The medicine man or chief conjuror of the village still takes an infant that is to be named to the hollowed stump of a forest tree filled with water, and in this primitive font the littl eNuba is dipped by the wizard, who makes on its forehead the sign of the Cross. It is natural that a people possessing of such traditions and such a history remained, as a rule, impervious to Islam. A few Meks learnt to profess a nominal submission to Mohamedanism, a very few joined the Mahdist movement, but the great mass remained pagan, and from the Arabs' point of view intractable.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:

Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MERCHANT SEAMEN'S HOME.
div.p: We have received from Mr. R.C. Crafton, honorary secretary of the Alexandria Merchant Seamen's Home, the annual report of the committee for the year ended 31st March last, which we publish with pleasure as affording particulars of work carried on for the benefit of seamen in this port. It is as follows:-

"The committee of the Alexandria Merchant Seamen's Home have satisfaction in the recording the completion by the Home of the 25th year of its existence. As a history of the Home was given at the formal opening of the new building, 15th January, 1901, published in the report of the committee that year, it may on the present occasion be sufficient to remark that the advantages, hoped for from the transference of the House to its present site within the Customs boundaries have been fully realized. To those who remember the disorderly scenes which frequently occurred in this neighbourhood of the hired premises formerly used as a Home, one of the most obvious ipovements is that which has taken place in the beahviour of the men. Great credit is undoubtedly due to Captain Dingle, the manager, for maintenance of discipline and good order, but that it has been possible to carry on the work of the Home as efficiently as at present is primarily due to the beneficent action of the authorities in granting the lease of a site on the quay, by which the committee were enabled to avail themselves of Mr. Alderson's generous offer of assistance in the removal of the Home to a place of safety and protection.

"The treasurer's statement of accounts compares favourably with that of the provious year. The receipts amount to £516.9.11 1/4 as against £424.4.3 1/4, or an increase of £92.5.8. This increase is drawn entirely from the Home itself, that is, on account of board and lodging, receipts from billiard tables, bar, etc. The expenditure is £104.13.5 3/4 in excess of the previous year, but includes cost of the new billiard table, and extra expense for provisions. The balance in hand is £177.10.4 3/4 as against £189.3.4 1/4 at 31st March 1905.

"During the past year various additions have been made to the attractions of the Home, and a proof of the estimation in which the institution is held by those for whose benefit it exists is to be found in the ever-increasing number of seamen availing themselves of the help it affords.

"The full-sized billiard table for the use of officers referred to in last year's report as being brought out from England, has been in use for nearly a year, this being in addition to the smaller one already existing, and such interest is displayed in the games that frequently of an evening there is not even standing space in the billiard room. A small billiard table, presented by the late Mr. Orel, is in use in the men's recreations room, this also being in addition to the two existing bagatelle tables. A pianoforte has been placed in the officers' room which has been subscribed for and presented by officers themselves.

The Egyptian Postal Administration has lately admitted the post-office at the Home to the postal money order service. This innovation should prove to boon to thousands of seamen coming to the port. During the year £732 were remitted by the men through the medium of the manager, and it is expected that during the coming year this amount will be largely exceeded, owing to increased facilities under the new arrangement.

The total number of boarders was 204. Of thes, 99 were boarded by the British Consulate, 25 were sent by the American, Swedish and Norwegian Consuls, 25 were sailors who paid their board and lodging, and 55 others.
Some idea of the work carried on at the Home may be obtained from the following statistics:-
During the year a large number of Scandinavian seamen have frequented the Home and the Post office, and were present at the entertainments.

"The supporters of an institution of this nature will be glad to hear that whilst attention is paid to the comfort and happiness of the men frequenting the Home, their spiritual needs are not forgotten. Divine service is conducted regularly every Sunday evening at 7:30, to which the sailors are invited by Captain Dingle, who visits them as soon as their ships arrive in harbour; and one cannot help remarking the heartiness of the singing and the earnestness of attention. These services are conducted under the auspices of St. Andrew's Church.

"As the work of the Home cannot be carried on without monetary assistance, the committee would ask those who take an interest in the well-being of seamen, but who have not as yeat contributed to the needs of the Home to do so, either personally , or from funds over which they may be able to exercise control. In referring to the list of subscribers the names of many old supporters will be found, as also of those who have lately responded, to all of whom the committee tender their thanks.

"In the course of the year in addition to the Christmas and New Year's treats again successfully organized by Lady Blomfield and Mrs. Moss on behalf of the town and Ramleh ladies respectively, there have been twelve concerts and teas provided for the entertainment of the men. To the many ladies and gentlemen who took part in these entertainments, or who in any way assisted Mr. Reid in the same, the committee tender their thanks.

We have to record our indebtedness to the following Editors and newspaper proprietors for kindly continuing to give copies of the publication gratis of the Home, viz, "Egyptian Gazette," "Weekly times," "Newcastle Chronicle," "Glasgow Mail," "Tit Bits," "Answers,", "Glasgow Herald."

It having been found necessary to increase the amount for which the Home is insured the committee have to acknowledge the kindness of Mr. Hewat in continuing to pay the insurance premium, this year on £2,800, and of May Pringle is auditing accounts.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Yesterday, at Victoria Barracks, Belfast, the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Colonel G.M. Mackenzie commanding, celebrated the 91st anniversary of the ever memorable Battle of Waterloo by "Trooping the Colour," a ceremony seldom seen nowadays in a regiment, but one which the gallant Inniskillings carry out on the 18th June annually. The following details of the ceremony will doubtless interest the 2nd Battallion at Cairo, if only for the mention of well known names in connection with it. The four guards having been formed up on the lower square, and inspected by Captain and Adjutant T.A.D. Best, at 4 p.m., he hadned over the parade to MAjor H.O.D. Hickman, who acted as Brigade Major.

In the centre the brass band and the drum and file band wre drawn up, and the colour - that last remaining link between the old 27th Inniskillings and the present 1st Battalion - was placed in front of the left of the line in charge of Colour Sergeant Delaney and guarded by a double sentry. Colonel Mackenzie then inspected the guards. OVer all the sun shone intermittently out of a blue sky in which rode masses of grey-white cloud, and there was that feeling of martial pomp and pageantry in the air which always characterises a military ceremony. The drums beat the assembly, marching across the parade in front of the guards formed into line, through the intervals of the band, then counter-marched and halted in the rear. Meanwhile the officers, Major Blennerhassett and Lieutenant Gordon, first guard; Captain G.W. Kenny and Lieutenant Henderson Scott, second guard; Captain Crawford and Lieutenant Maunders, third guard; and Captain G.W. Kennedy and Lieutenant Henderson Scott, second guard; Captain Crawford and Lieutenant MAunders, third guard; and Captain Atkinson and Lieutenant Hammond Smith, fourth guard - marched up in front of the senior sergeant attached to each company, and at the command of the Brigade Major they slowly marched up the parade ground and took post in front of their respective guards. The band and drums, the former under the baton of Bandmaster Turner, and the latter headed by Drum Seargeant Arbuckle, then played a slow march, moving from irhgt to left of the line, and counter marched in front of the colour, afterwards returning playing a quick march, and halted and ceased playing when in front of the right line. The drummers call was then given, and the captain commanding the guard on the extreme right having taken up a post in front of No. 2 guard, the escort for the colour moved off formed to the left, and marched direct to the colour. Sergeant Major Bleakley here received the grand old colour surmounted with with its victor's crown of laurel leaf, and returned with it to the escort at slow step, subsequently handing it over to Colour Lieutenant Kenny, who, after saluting it, placed it in his belt, and turned toward the escort, who presented arms to the left of line and passed down the ranks of the guards, who presented arms. The escort was halted at the right of the line, and the guards having marched past the saluting base, formed into line and the colour was marched of to the accompaniement of music and the guards were dismissed. Thus the bare and unconvincing narrative of a brilliant spectacle, at which there was not a spectator, wit the least patriotic ardour who did not feel thrilled and intensely interested in the proceedings. The Inniskillings have good reason to be proud of their participation in the glorious victory of 91 years ago, when Napoleon was finally overthrown and his despotic power destroyed forever. The old 27th bore themselves like true men and gallant soldiers, and though many of them died bravely at their posts, forming that unflinching human barrier at the cross-roads, their memory is not forgotte, and they have left an imperishable record of bravery and courage never excelled in the annuals of human endurance and heroism. It is, therefore, with added significance that the present members of the regiment go through the stately ceremony of trooping the colour.

Lieutenant Colonel A.W. Roper, Royal Engineers, latterly an Instructor at the School of Military Engineering, has been selected for the appointment of C.R.E. in Egypt, in succession to Lieutenant Colonel Mantell, who comes home to take up a similar appointment at Cork. The new C.R.E. has served in the Sappers since February, 1882, he was promoted captain in 1890, major in 1899, and lieutenant colonel a short time ago. He is no stranger to Egypt, having seen active service in the Sudan Campaign of 1885-85 with the Nile Column (medal with clasp, and Khedive's star). His next war service was in South Africa during the campaign of 1900-02, his services in the field embracing the operations leading up to the cornering of [nR] at Paardeberg, the actions of Poplar Grove, Driefontien, relief of Kimberley, and the guerilla warfare in Orange River Colony, Cape Colony, and the Transvaal (mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, Queen's medal with three clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

Captains C.R. Terret and C.F. Wilkins, Inniskilling Dragoons, who have just been promoted to that rank, entered the regiment in December 1899, and May 1900, respectively. Captain Terret, who is adjutant of the Royal North Davon Hussars I.Y. served with the Inniskillings in the South African War, including the fighting in the Orange Free State, Transvaal, and Orange River Colony (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

Captain Wilkins got his commission in May 1900, from the local Natal forces. As a noncommissioned officer he served in the defence of Ladysmith, and was present at the actions of Elandslaatge, Rietfontein, and Lombard's Kop, which preceded the siege, and the desperate attack on Ladysmith, 6th January, 1900, and the action of Laing's nek. In the succeeding operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony he saw a lot of service and did good work in handling his men in one of De Wet's attacks on our convoys (Queen's medal with six clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

Second Lieutenants E.V. Knox and E.F. Seymour, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, serving with the 1st Battalion at Alexandria and the 2nd Battalion at Buttevant respectively, have been promoted lieutenants, Lieutenant Knox got his first commission in the Dublins in March, 1901, from the unattached list, and had some experience of war in South Afircan campagin, 1901-1902, including the operations in the Transvaal and on the Zululand fronteir (Queen's medal with three clasps). Lieutenant and similarly. He served in the transvall opeatings.

div.head: HELPLESS WITH RHEUMATISM.
div.p: The case of Mr. George West, of 161 Evenelyn Street, Deptford, London, England, is exceptionally interesting. Mr. West says "I used to think I should go mad with the constant suffering from kidney trouble and rheumatism. I could nget no peace, no rest, no comfort, day or night. It made people ill to see me struggling to walk. My back was so weak that I thought it would break in two,a nd at last I lost the use of my limbs, and my feet had no feelings in them. The pains in my back were just as though some one were pulling the joints out of the sockets. The rheumatism doubled me up, and I used to wish I could die and be out of it all. But now I am well and bright again. I can get about without the sticks I had to use before and I enjoy splendid health. It was right back in June 1903 that Doan's Pills made me well, yet I am still well, and believe my cure to be a lasting one. This testimony is quite unsolicited, and you are welcome to use it."

Mr. Edward G. Evans, of 135 Childers Stree, London, kindly endorses the facts of Mr. West's splendid cure by Doan's backache Kidney pills in the following - "Before using Doan's pills, Mr. WEst was away from business five months, and was so disabled with rheumatism that at every step he took his knees nearly touched the ground. It was awful to see him trying to walk and at last he could only just manage to move about by using sticks. He is splendid and well now and has kept well ever since his cure although that was over a year ago."

Rheumatism shows a lax condition of the kidneys, and the presence of uric acid in the system in great excess. It is often accompanied by other kidney symptoms, such as gravel or stones, watery swellings in the flesh, cloudy urine, thick settlement... After the water has been standing 24 hours. Urine is scalding and painful in passing, there is a feeling of weariness and pain in the back, and the patient aches in every limb.

Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are successful in curing these kidney troubles because they dissolve the crystallised uric acid and urea and increase the flow of urine by which the impurities are flushed out of the system, and the kidney organism cleansed and restored to health.
Doan's Dinner Pills are sold by all chemmists and druggists at P.T 13 per box, or P.T 71 for 6 boxes, or they may be bought direct from the general agent for Egypt, Max FIscher, Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
EXTRACTS FROM HOME PAPERS.
div.p: It will be a long time yet, if we may judge from such signs as are visible, before the ations of Euroope embark on disarmament, as a practical policy. In the meantime, however, there are influences at work which make more gradually, but not less surely, for peace. Highest among them we must rankt hose understandings between nations which, supplementing the older alliances, draw symptahies closer and provide fresh and weighty arguments against an appeal to the sword.

div.head: The Attraction of Empire
div.p: As a fact, we know beyond possibility of doubt that thousands of British citizens will emigrate from these shores each year, with or without the recognition of Government departments. The thing is like a natural force in its certainty. Certain parts of our own Imperial estate need these people, and can offter them self-respecting independence under the British Flag. Such is the nature of those tracts of the Empire that they will in any case attract settlers, whether of our race of some other.

div.head: The Denishwai Tragedy.
div.p: The spread of the Pan Islamic agitation must be giving Lord Cromer no little anxiety. The old Turks covet a return of the happy times when they could plunder the public revenue, and as British control is incompatible with that restoration, the clique of sordid conspirators strain every endeavour to get rid of it by one method or another. The Pan-Islamic movement is accordingly enlisted for the purpose, as the readiest means of drawing all Mohamedans together against the Christian community. The Sultan was, no doubt, Chiefly encouraged by this got-up religious fermentation to tend troops across the Turco-Egyptian frontier, hoping no donbt, that Mukhtar Pasha, his agent at Cairo, would help the armed enterprise by covertly preaching sedition. But when strong British reinforcements arrived, the plot collapsed, and there is just a possibility that the outrage near Tantah was an after consequence of the previous unrest.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny.
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres reste toujours invarié à 3 1/4 pour cent.

Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de non moins de 5/8 de livre à 80 1/8. L’Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 3/4, de même que la National Bank à 25 5/8, la Daira à 17 1/8 et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Fonciér Egyptien a perdu 1 franc à 771. La Banque d’Athène est demeurée inchangée à 154.
Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, aujourd'hui, moins animé, moins actif qu’hier. Toutefois, les dispositions ne sont pas mauvaises, bien que la fermeté ne se soit pas maintenue sur toute la ligne.

Pen d’afiaireè en National Bank, qui à couturé à 25 1/2-9/16. L’Agricolé s’est tenue à son prix d’hier, soit 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto s’est alourdie à 213 l’action ancienne, ainsi que la Banque d’Athènes à 154 et la Banque d’Orient à 131 1/2.
L’action Crédit Foncier a molli à 770 et là part de fondateur à 910.
L’action Immobilière a fléchi à 366, l’Entreprise and Development à 11 15/16 et l’Agricole du Nil à 259; la part de fondateur a progressé, par contre, à 7 1/16.
Bonne demande en Improvements Corporation, qui a gagné 1/8 à 4 11/16 3/4.
L’action Entreprises Immobilière et Tra-vâux a’est raffermie à 4 1/16; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, a avancé à 70.
L’action Wardan Estate s’est inscrite à 6 et la,Nile Land à 13 1/2.
La part de fondateur Land Allotment a encore faibli à 110.
L’action de capital Eaux du Caire a fait 120-121; les Jouissances ont clôturé à 261 1/2 après avoir atteint 264.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich, délaissés, sont restés à 15 7/16 l’action anciene, et 15 3/8 la nouvelle. Les Baehler ont débuté à 5 23/32 pour finir à 5 21/32 11/16. Lee National ont progressé à 3 3/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été' ramenés à 3 13/16 et les Glymenopoulo à 1 9/16.
Nous détachons d’une lettre de Londres, en date du 19 Juin, les lignes suivantes concernant la situation monétaire:

"Les conditions de l’argent se sont avanta-geaiement modifiées. L’encaisse de la Banque d’Angleterre s’est considérablement accru et la proportion de la réserve s’est élevée à plus de 47%. Le taux de l’escompte libre oscille entre 8 3/8 et 3 1/4 pour cent. La situation est donc, sans conteste, meilleure, bien que les disponibilités du marché aient à faire face à l'emprunt irlandais, annoncé pour le 7 Juillet; là tenue du cours du Consolidé anglais en est affectée. Le “Statist” ne prévoit pas une augmentation prochaine des disponibilités et s’attend même à des sorties considérables poor la fin du mois courant.

Le Stock Exchange jouit en ce moment d’un repos relatif; c'est l’effet de la morte saison. Là clientèle est devenue rare, et les mouvements des valeurs quelque peu somnolentes ont beaucoup perdu de leur étendue."
On annonce d’Athènes que L’assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires de la Banque du Crédit Industriel de Grèce, tenue samedi passé, a voté à l’unanimité la fusion avec la Banque d’Athènes.
L’assemblée extraordinaire de la Banque d’Athènes, qui doit statuer sur le même objet; est fixée comme on sait; au samedi 7 Juillet prochain.

On assure que l’arrangement négocié entre le gouvernement et la Société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d’Egyptè concernant l’achat par l’Etat des lignes de railways à voie étroite de cet té Société serait sur le point d’être conclu, au prix d’environ LE. 350,000.

Au dire d’un journal d’Alexandrie, un groupe financier, à la tête daquel se trouverait M. Scott, ancien directeur de la Compagnie d’assurance "The Gresham," se propose de former une Société anonyme de constructions economiques dont le siege social serait au Caire:

"Les acheteurs-locataires deviendraient pro priétaires au bout d’un certain nombrè d’années en payant un loyer comprenant l’amortis sement du prix de l’immeuble et une prime d’assurance, de sorte qu’en cas de mort leurs héritiers deviendraient par le fait propriétaires.”

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a encore perdu hier 1/4 de livre à 87 7/8. L'Unifée est restée invariée à 104 3/4, de même que la National Bank à 25 5/8, l'Agricole à 9 5/8, la Daïra à 17 1/8 et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clôturé en baisse de 2 francs à 769. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée-inchangée à 154.
Ici, notre marché a présenté plus ou moins, aujourd hui, les mêmes caracteristiques qu'hier séance calme, avec affaires restreintes et tendance générale indécise.

La National Bank et l'Agricole, delaissees, ont clôtúre a leurs cours précédents. Rien de particulier à relever sur les antres valeurs du compartiment, à ceci pres que la Banque d'Abyssinie a été offerte à 5 3/4.
Le Crèdit Foncier a rétrogradé à 767, la Daïra à 17 1/16 et la Béhéra à 36. La part de fondateur, Wardan Estate a perdu 1/4 à 7.

L'action Immobiliére s'est maintenue à 365-366; la part de fondateur a gagne 6 francs à 576. L'action Agricole du Nil a avancé à 262. L'Improvements Corporation a reactionné à 4 11/16 L'Union Foncière est revenue à 6 3/16.
L'action Land Allotment a fléchi à 3 1/8-3/16, la part de fondateur est restée à 110.
Les actions privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie ont hausse de 4 francs à 192, et les dividendes de 2 francs à 357.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich se sont raffermis à 15 7/16 1/2 l'action ancienne. Les Baehler ont molli à 5 5/8. Les National ont encore gagné 1/16 à 3 3/8 7/16. L'Anglo American Nile a perdu 1/16 à 5 1/16.

Parmilles petites valeurs, les Delta Land on faibli à 3 11/16 3/4 et les Glymenopoulo à 1 1/2 9/16, malgré leur fusion avec la Building Lands Co., qui a été votée hier; elle devra etre confirmée dans quina jours par une antre assemblée extraordinaire la part de fondateur Estates a reculé de 1/8 à 10 1/16. Les New Egyptian ont clôturé a 29 sh. 3 et les Egyptian Constructions à 1 1/16-1/8. Les Khedivial Mail ont fait 32 shellings.

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. div.p: Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatologists in the treatment of eczema, lepra, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contraoting disease and infectious disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimise the inconvenienoes of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, tecacne. In Tablets, price 1s. sold by Max Fischer. Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier, DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs' les dernieres statistiques jusqu'a la veille de sa publication des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association etc. etc.
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute q L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
